repnme.cdata!:
Jamaica - Education Program Preparation and
            Student Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Education Program Preparation and
            Student Loan Project in Jamaica. The main objectives of the
            project were to prepare, pilot, and evaluate options for
            cost-effective measures for qualitative improvement of basic
            education (with particular emphasis on Grades 7-9), and more
            efficient administration and targeting of the Student's
            Loan Program (SLP) for higher education. The Bank's
            performance in most stages of the project cycle was
            satisfactory. Borrower’s performance was satisfactory. The
            most significant lessons learned from the implementation
            experience of this project are: (i) although the Ministry of
            Education was effective in implementing the education
            components, it did not perform well in contracting or
            managing civil works; (ii) to increase the financial
            sustainability and administrative efficiency of student loan
            programs, significant attention should be given, and
            enforceable covenants included in the Loan Agreement and
            monitored; (iii) the complexity of government procurement
            procedures are evident in this project and in other
            Bank-supported projects; and (iv) the Bank should be
            extremely cautious in granting project extension requests
            for projects that have experienced such difficulties.

Jamaica - Education Program Preparation and
            Student Loan Project

repnme.cdata!:
Jamaica - A study of the reform of
            secondary education : fourth World Bank - 1990

abstracts.cdata!:
This study summarizes the deliberations
            and conclusions of a number of consultants who were invited
            to consider proposals for the reform of secondary education
            in Jamaica. For a six-month period in 1989 and a one-month
            period in 1990, the study group addressed the terms of
            reference prepared by the Ministry of Education, i.e. the
            rationalization of existing institutional types, development
            of new curricula, and the feasibility of a unified lower
            secondary cycle. In 1983, a United Nations Educational,
            Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) report on
            education in Jamaica had suggested a common curriculum for
            the lower cycle of secondary schools.  The study begins with
            an overview in chapter one of the present system, the
            historical forces which still shape it, and the major
            problems which need to be addressed. The basic reasons were
            outlined in chapter two. Recommendations for focus and
            balance in the curriculum are presented in chapters three
            and four. The main objective of the current reform of the
            Jamaican secondary education system is the definition of a
            common curriculum for all the students of grades seven-nine
            is presented in chapter five. A plan for teacher education
            and staff development is presented in chapter six.  Finally,
            in chapter seven, an enhanced operational role for school
            boards within the context of strong central planning by the
            Ministry of Education is described. An incremental strategy
            for implementation is presented as a guide to the work of
            school boards and the Ministers and officials of the
            Ministry in the task of introducing and implementing the reforms.

docna.cdata!:
Jamaica - A study of the reform of secondary
            education : fourth World Bank - 1990

repnme.cdata!:
Jamaica - Education Program Preparation and
            Student Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Education Program Preparation and
            Student Loan Program Project seeks to (i) assist the
            Government to prepare and evaluate options for a basic
            education rehabilitation and development program, and (ii)
            strengthen the Government's student loan program for
            higher education.  The project includes:  (a) a
            comprehensive technical assistance package; (b) in-service
            training of teachers, supervisors, and Ministry of Education
            (MOE) management staff; (c) a pilot project for
            consolidation of about 20 small all-age schools; and (d)
            funds to expand the students' loan program for higher
            education.  Finally, the project provides (e) computing
            equipment for the Students' Loan Bureau (SLB) and the
            MOE Planning Office.

docna.cdata!:
Jamaica - Education Program Preparation and
            Student Loan Project

Jamaica - Education Program
